Module lanat
Package lanat

Class Argument<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner>

java.lang.Object
lanat.Argument<Type,TInner>
Type Parameters:
Type - the ArgumentType subclass that will parse the value passed to the argument
TInner - the actual type of the value passed to the argument
All Implemented Interfaces:
ArgumentGroupUser, CommandUser, MultipleNamesAndDescription, NamedWithDescription, ErrorCallbacks<TInner,Argument<Type,TInner>>, ErrorsContainer<CustomError>, Resettable
public class Argument<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner> extends Object implements ErrorsContainer<CustomError>, ErrorCallbacks<TInner,Argument<Type,TInner>>, Resettable, CommandUser, ArgumentGroupUser, MultipleNamesAndDescription

Argument

An Argument specifies a value that the user can introduce to the command. This value will be parsed by the specified ArgumentType each time the Argument is used. Once finished parsing, the value may be retrieved by using ParsedArguments.get(String) on the ParsedArguments object returned by ArgumentParser.parse(CLInput).

An Argument can be created using the factory methods available, like createOfBoolType(String...).



Example:

An Argument with the names "name" and 'n' that will parse an integer value. In order to create an Argument, you need to call any of the static factory methods available, like createOfBoolType(String...). These methods will return an ArgumentBuilder object, which can be used to specify the Argument's properties easily. 

 
     Argument.create('n', "name", new IntegerArgumentType());
     Argument.create("name", new IntegerArgumentType())
         .addNames("n");

Argument usage

The argument can be used in the following ways:
  • Specifying the whole name with the prefix: "--name 32" or "-name 32".

    An equals sign can be used instead of a space: "--name=32" or "-name=32".

  • Since the argument in the example above has a single character name, this is also possible: "-n32".
See Also:
  • Command.addArgument(Argument)
  • ArgumentGroup
  • ArgumentParser

      @NotNull public final Type extends ArgumentType<TInner> argType
      The type of this argument. This is the subParser that will be used to parse the value/s this argument should receive.

    • create

      public static <Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>, TInner> ArgumentBuilder<Type,TInner> create(@NotNull Type argType, char charName, @NotNull @NotNull String fullName)
      Creates an argument builder with the specified single character name, full name and type.

      This is equivalent to calling 

      Argument.create(charName, argType).addNames(fullName)
      Parameters:
      charName - the single character name of the argument.
      fullName - the full name of the argument.
      argType - the type of the argument. This is the subParser that will be used to parse the value/s this

    • setPositional

      public void setPositional(boolean positional)
      Marks the argument as positional. This means that the value of this argument may be specified directly without indicating a name of this argument. The positional place where it should be placed is defined by the order of creation of the argument definitions.
      • Note that an argument marked as positional can still be used by specifying a name.

    • isPositional

      Returns true if this argument is positional.
      Returns:
      true if this argument is positional.
      See Also:

    • setPrefix

      public void setPrefix(Argument.PrefixChar prefixChar)
      Specify the prefix of this argument. By default, this is Argument.PrefixChar.MINUS. If this argument is used in an argument name list (-abc), the prefix that will be valid is any against all the arguments specified in that name list.
      Parameters:
      prefixChar - the prefix that should be used for this argument.
      See Also:
      • Argument.PrefixChar

    • getPrefix

      public Argument.PrefixChar getPrefix()
      Returns the prefix of this argument.
      Returns:
      the prefix of this argument.

    • setAllowUnique

      public void setAllowUnique(boolean allowUnique)
      Specifies that this argument has priority over other arguments, even if they are obligatory. This means that if an argument in a command is set as obligatory, but one argument with allowUnique was used, then the unused obligatory argument will not throw an error.

    • isUniqueAllowed

      public boolean isUniqueAllowed()
      Returns true if this argument has priority over other arguments, even if they are obligatory.
      Returns:
      true if this argument has priority over other arguments, even if they are obligatory.
      See Also:
      • setAllowUnique(boolean)

    • setDefaultValue

      public void setDefaultValue(@Nullable TInner value)
      The value that should be used if the user does not specify a value for this argument. If the argument does not accept values, this value will be ignored.
      Parameters:
      value - the value that should be used if the user does not specify a value for this argument. If the value is null, then no default value will be used.

    • addNames

      public void addNames(@NotNull @NotNull String... names)
      Add more names to this argument. This is useful if you want the same argument to be used with multiple different names.

      Single character names can be used in argument name lists (e.g. -abc), each alphabetic character being an argument name, that is, -a -b -c.

      Specified by:
      addNames in interface MultipleNamesAndDescription
      Parameters:
      names - the names that should be added to this argument.

    • finishParsing

      @Nullable public TInner finishParsing()
      This method is called when the command is finished parsing. And should only ever be called once (per parse).
      Returns:
      the final value parsed by the argument type, or the default value if the argument was not used.

    • checkMatch

      public boolean checkMatch(@NotNull @NotNull String name)
      Checks if this argument matches the given name, including the prefix.

      For example, if the prefix is '-' and the argument has the name "help", this method will return true if the name is "--help".

      Parameters:
      name - the name to check
      Returns:
      true if the name matches, false otherwise.

    • equals

      public boolean equals(@NotNull @NotNull Object obj)
      Returns true if the argument specified by the given name is equal to this argument.

      Equality is determined by the argument's name and the command it belongs to.

      Overrides:

    • compareByPriority

      public static int compareByPriority(@NotNull @NotNull Argument<?,?> first, @NotNull @NotNull Argument<?,?> second)
      Compares two arguments by the synopsis view priority order.

      Order: Allows Unique > Positional > Obligatory > Optional.

      Parameters:
      first - the first argument to compare
      second - the second argument to compare
      Returns:
      0 if both arguments are equal, -1 if the first argument goes before the second, 1 if the second goes before the first.

    • sortByPriority

    • setOnErrorCallback

      public void setOnErrorCallback(@Nullable @Nullable Consumer<@NotNull Argument<Type,TInner>> callback)
      Specify a function that will be called if an error occurs when parsing this argument.

      Note that this callback is only called if the error was dispatched by this argument's type. That is, if the argument, for example, is obligatory, and the user does not specify a value, an error will be thrown, but this callback will not be called, as the error was not dispatched by this argument's type.

      Specified by:
      setOnErrorCallback in interface ErrorCallbacks<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner>
      Parameters:
      callback - the function that will be called if an error occurs when parsing this argument.

    • setOnOkCallback

      public void setOnOkCallback(@Nullable @Nullable Consumer<@NotNull TInner> callback)
      Specify a function that will be called with the value introduced by the user.

      By default this callback is called only if all commands succeed, but you can change this behavior with Command.setCallbackInvocationOption(CallbacksInvocationOption)

      Specified by:
      setOnOkCallback in interface ErrorCallbacks<Type extends ArgumentType<TInner>,TInner>
      Parameters:
      callback - the function that will be called with the value introduced by the user.

    • invokeCallbacks

      public void invokeCallbacks()
      NOTE: Only invokes the error callback! Use invokeCallbacks(Object) for invoking both.
      Specified by:
